answer_html: Given a counting, that is such a bijection \(f\) the first element of the set A is the one that is mapped to 1 by the function, the second element is the one mapped to 2 and so on.Observe that we need to require the function to be bijective to guarantee that all the elements are counted and are counted in a unique way (we don’t want to have two elements mapped to the same natural number).
answer_latex:
Given a
counting, that is such a bijection $f$ the \emph{first} element of the set
\emph{A} is the one that is mapped to 1 by the function, the
\emph{second} element is the one mapped to 2 and so on.Observe that we
need to require the function to be bijective to guarantee that all the
elements are counted and are counted in a unique way (we don't want to
have two elements mapped to the same natural number).
hints_html: The word “denumerable” suggests natural numbers. Denumerable is another word for countably infinite.
hints_latex:
The word ``denumerable'' suggests natural numbers. Denumerable is
another word for \emph{countably infinite}.
hints_raw: The word "denumerable" suggests natural numbers. Denumerable is another word for ''countably infinite''.
question: 5 (a)
sols_html:
A set A is denumerable if it is in bijective correspondence with the natural numbers. That is, it is denumerable if and only if there exists a bijective function

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f: A \to \mathbb{N}\end{aligned}\]

Note: Mathematicians think of this function as a counting of all the elements of the set A. Given a counting, that is such a bijection \(f\) the first element of the set A is the one that is mapped to 1 by the function, the second element is the one mapped to 2 and so on. Observe that we need to require the function to be bijective to guarantee that all the elements are counted and are counted in a unique way (we don’t want to have two elements mapped to the same natural number).
sols_latex:
A set \emph{A} is denumerable if it is in bijective correspondence with
the natural numbers. That is, it is denumerable if and only if there
exists a bijective function

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
f: A \to \mathbb{N}
\end{align*}

\textbf{Note:} Mathematicians think of this function as a
\emph{counting} of all the elements of the set \emph{A}. Given a
counting, that is such a bijection $f$ the \emph{first} element of the set
\emph{A} is the one that is mapped to 1 by the function, the
\emph{second} element is the one mapped to 2 and so on. Observe that we
need to require the function to be bijective to guarantee that all the
elements are counted and are counted in a unique way (we don't want to
have two elements mapped to the same natural number).
sols_raw:
A set ''A'' is denumerable if it is in bijective correspondence with the natural numbers. That is, it is denumerable if and only if there exists a bijective function
:<math>\displaystyle
f: A \to \mathbb{N}
</math>


'''Note:''' Mathematicians think of this function as a ''counting'' of all the elements of the set ''A''. Given a counting, that is such a bijection &fnof; the ''first'' element of the set ''A'' is the one that is mapped to 1 by the function, the ''second'' element is the one mapped to 2 and so on. Observe that we need to require the function to be bijective to guarantee that all the elements are counted and are counted in a unique way (we don't want to have two elements mapped to the same natural number).
statement_html: State what is means for a set A to be denumerable.
statement_latex: State what is means for a set \emph{A} to be denumerable.
statement_raw: State what is means for a set ''A'' to be denumerable.
